description.text: Alpha Incipiens -- First Beginnings The Alpha Incipiens Mars Base is designed for the beginnings of Mars colonization. Its modular design allows for massive customization to fully meet the needs of the colony. Colony Heart: This centerpiece provides the access to all other parts of the colony. With retractable "hallway arms", it can connect to any other modular piece the colony needs. Equipped with solar panels on top, it stores energy for use elsewhere in the colony. A satellite dish provides communication abilities back to earth and to other satellites. Housing: Built to look similar to earth housing, it provides a comfortable place for the colonizers to rest. Equipped with solar panels, it is completely powered by the sun, and stores additional energy for use elsewhere. Research Center: The Research Center provides the colony with the perfect place to perform experiments and take notes of life on Mars. The satellite dish relays the information back to earth. Air Lock: The air lock is designed to give colonizers a place to access the outside world of Mars. It provides a safe place to leave and enter the colony without putting the rest of the colony in danger. In addition, it serves as a connection to other colony hearts. Storage Container: The storage container is designed to hold the many tools, packaged food, drink, and other supplies that a mars colony will need to survive. Equipped with solar panels on top, it provides energy to other places in the colony. Green House: The green house will be the main source of food, where a system of aquaponics provides ample nutrition to the colony. Martian light will fuel the growth of food. Efficient design of the greenhouse interiors gives plenty of room to grow numerous varieties of food for long periods of time. Escape Pod: The escape pod provides a quick emergency escape for the colony. In the unlikely event of a disaster, the escape pod will easily hold the colony. With equipped food and fuel, the colony will comfortably be able to escape back to earth. Now, is this scientifically feasible? Surprisingly, yes it is. The modular design of the community can easily adapt to any colony's specific needs. In addition, the modular design provides an easy way to actually get the colony to mars and to quickly assemble to support human life. Power is provided by ample sunlight, food is grown in the greenhouse and sent from earth, water is mined for and stored, and colonizers will be comfortable in the housing and other supplied rooms.

Each piece designed for easy printing.   
Scale to fit your needs, it comes fairly large in the file.   
Print each file to fit your specific colony's needs!   
Help your colony thrive!

NOTE: all models are at initial stage and not refined, nor optimized for printing, only a rough idea at the moment The unmanned colony builder/Mars MkI is a project that seeks to automate the construction of shelters and basic facilities that a colony would require. The goal is to send in an initial amount of machinery and materials to mars, then the colony builds it'self to await colonists' arrival. Overview:
1.Shelter
2.Power
3.Life Support
4.Communications
5.Landing Pad
6.Science
7.Manufacturing 1.Shelter:
The shelter includes : living quarters, maintenance and life support, connection ducts(green house, solar panels), manufacturing, power, underground storage and passageways, science and communication(central command) Shelter are built from transformable exteriors of the payload that carried the machinery and material to mars. Secondary shelters are manufactured from materials found on mars. A high Temperature furnace (electric arc or similar electric furnace used in basaltic smelting) will first melt the martian regolith (mainly basaltic) into molten lava form. The molten lava will then either be processed into usable parts for glass or metals or form pellets that can be transported and used by the "printing modules"
Due to the climate on mars, these shelters have a low profile and octagonal shapes to deflect sand storms. solar panels and green house modules are designed to be extendable and shielded from external environment. The internal habitat would be pressurized where the base of the complex being formed during excavating the foundation with cooled molten rocks as walls 2.Power
There are a few possible options for power; solar, thermal, nuclear, wind and geothermal.
The interior of connectors are fitted with solar panels and the exterior with solar thermal gathering system. also, a solar furnace is incorporated for both melting basaltic rocks and thermal generation for generators.
The exterior bodies are designed with Thermoelectric materials and would power the ventilation system and LEDs for indoor temperature and lighting. An underground thermal chamber is used for storing cold martian atmosphere from night times and used as coolant throughout the facilities. The thermal difference is also used to generate power.
Wind power from the dust storm could be used for power generation and is adapted into the combined shaft for ventilation underneath the facilities. This way the wind speed could be controlled as well as using the turbines when there is no wind.
These combined methods will primarily power the life support system, any excess power would be sent to mining and manufacture(electric furnace and printing module).
It was considered to install a nuclear reactor to fully power the machinery, hopefully the lower gravity of mars won't require a reactor to run the colony. 3.Life support
Air, water, food. The main necessities of life. Water is available on mars near the polar caps or in aqueous minerals, but the majority of the water would be recycled. Vegetation is grown in the green house or hydroponics bay and with Sabatier reaction, air and water are recycled with the extra methane going to power or manufacturing. Fertile soil production from residues of the mining process would add to creating soils for cultivation. 4.Communications
To prevent "going dark" orbital satellites are required for communications and surveillance. This module would also be responsible for central command and oversees the colony. The communications tower would suffice proximity areas of the colony but any further would require satellites to relay the information. 5.Landing pad
A flat hardened area for space crafts and surveillance drones to land/take off. hexagonal shape allows customized layout. The landing pad is also situated above the underground storage and ventilation system. This is also the hanger for autonomous machines for recharge, repairs and maintenance.
  • Science
    A small Laboratory capable of small scale manufacturing and contains the central computer mainframe for the colony.
    • 7.Manufacturing
    Comprised from mining with automated diggers and grinders to construction and fabrication of materials. The soft and brittle surface of mars should allow diggers to dig for a foundation and then the pieces would be heated in the furnace and the molten lava could be used like concrete to set the foundation and print walls.
    Metals and mineral extraction could also be done during this.
    Construction relies on self assembling parts and the lava printer. The printer is a mobile platform that has 4 robotic arms where 2 are heating elements and 2 are cooling and smoothing guide. The mobility is provided by the treads and retractable stabilizers. Basically in a nut shell it is a foundation system that can process raw materials and build a closed environment as well as providing necessities for life.
It is based on Asymmetry...a new world that have been hiden from Us all...

title: Mars Base Alpha - Mars Base Contest Entry

description.text: I've designed this permanent settlement center on Mars for safety, livability, and scientific exploration.  Viewing the exterior of the base, the large building in the foreground is the central base. The two corridors lead to the landing structures. The straight corridor leads to the rocket landing pad. The second leads to the probe landing pad. There are three satellite dishes for communication next to the probe landing pad. There is a large field of solar panels adjacent to the satellite dishes that are connected to a small building that collects their power and transfers it to the central base. The solar panels can collapse to a height of two feet and a wall surrounding the field can rise to four feet. A slightly curved roof will extend over the area to protect the panels from storms. For the interior of the base, the bottom floor is used for the storage of food, water, oxygen, spare parts, space probes, and space suits. The second level is used for crew quarters and also contains a fuel cell with a generator. The control center in the second level usually directs system operations but the control over systems can be switched to either level. The generator on the second level is used for power and can also filter air in and out of the base. Internal carbon dioxide is flushed to the greenhouses on the third level and the generator will also filter in oxygen from the outside to save reserves. The third level is used to house gardens for food and oxygen and contains a secondary control center that primarily monitors systems. The ladders on each level have lockers next to them in case a level is breached and can only be used by those in space suits. There are air tight doors for each room and ladder entrance in case of a exterior wall breach. The base will be transported by six rockets:  one for the solar panels and probes, one for the satellite dishes, another for main base and computers, two for spare parts, oxygen, and landing pads, and a final one for food and supplies. #MakerBotMars
I used Sketchup Pro.

author: gochya

description.text:
This MakerBotMars challenge entry design recognises the fundamental constraint in building a Mars base, which is that minimal material can be sent from Earth. I have responded to this constraint by printing the habitats from concrete or a similar material manufactured on Mars. House printing using concrete is a cutting edge technology at present with the first generation small house printers announced for sale recently. Significant earthly technology development is expected over the next decades, but rapid Mars-oriented technology research and development will be needed to be able to locate suitable rock/regolith for concrete manufacture, quarry it, process it to cement, locate, acquire and store water (or maybe some other liquid?) for mixing the cement and controlling the quality for consistent application, then protecting the printed building while the concrete cures. All this presumably needs to be done robotically so that the buildings are in-place when humans arrive, if not totally fitted out. As Mars-based mineral processing develops, more sophisticated buildings will be possible using a greater range of materials. However this entry represents a first non-imported habitat. Three other critical constraints have shaped my design.

  • Because of the extreme cold temperatures and high range of temperatures encountered on Mars, a triple-skinned design has been adopted. Each skin is separated by a void which would be kept at the low ambient atmospheric pressure of Mars, and which would therefore stop convective heat loss from the inner skins, much as a vacuum flask keeps coffee warm. Some low emissivity surface treatment of the facing surfaces of the skins may be needed to reduce radiant heat transfer. This could be installed during printing.

  • Because Mars' atmospheric pressure is only around 1% of Earth's, the habitats will need to be pressurised, reliably and with backup, and one or several airlocks will be needed for people to access the habitat. Each of the 3 skins is designed to e able to hold the pressure required inside the habitat, although in normal operation earth pressure would only be retained in the inner skin, to maximise the insulation effect of the voids. If a leak occurred in the inner skin, this could be detected through rising pressure in the voids, and contained by an outer skin.
    A series of three air locks are provided, so that at any one time a minimum of 3 doors are closed between unprotected people inside the habitat and the outside low pressure atmosphere. This redundancy allows safety in the unlikely circumstance of simultaneous leakage of 2 doors. Entering the habitat the first air lock would be used for tool storage and gross decontamination. The second lock might provide compressed Martian 'air' for blowing/vacuuming dust off pressure suits. The third lock, at full earth pressure and composition is for suit storage and changing into indoor clothes. The colour coded cutaway image shows the 3 skins, two of the airlocks, inverted pyramid support structures for the inner skins, and bracing between the skins.
    No windows are provided as they would allow heat loss, would abrade quickly in Mars'Â dust storms, would not be part of early Mars-based manufacturing capability, and would be an extravagance to carry from earth. On the other hand pressure doors are critical equipment, and would need to be brought from earth and carefully fitted to the airlocks, possibly by the first arrivals.
    The rounded corners on the skins are designed to make them more resistant to the pressure difference between the inside and outside. It is assumed that the Martian concrete can be made strong enough to contain the pressure - either through careful manufacture, or the addition of a small fibrous component brought from Earth or manufactured on Mars.

  • Printing the habitat brings another major constraint - 3D additive printers cannot print unsupported overhangs much steeper than about 45 degrees. It isn't clear whether Mars' reduced gravity might allow steeper overhangs, but a 45 degree limit has been adopted for this design, along with the prohibition of temporary support structures which would only provide work for new human arrivals, when there would be much higher priorities for their time.
    This constraint leads directly to the peaked roofline of the habitats, as this is what could be directly printed. This gives the habitats a rather childlike housy look that immediately says 'humans are here to stay'. The peaked door openings and the inverted pyramid basal support structures are also a result of the constraint on printing overhangs.
    • The habitats are designed to be printed directly onto a pre-smoothed firm base of regolith by a tractor-based robot arm printer which would build up layers at 45 degrees to the horizontal as the tractor moves slowly forward. Habitats could be constructed singly, or fused into chains sharing the one outer skin or maybe two, but retaining separate inner skins, and linked by pressure doors for safety. Joining two or more habitats in this way provides multiple redundancy in case of airlock failure, pressure failure etc. The printing tractor would be fed printing supplies by an independant robotic vehicle transporting cement and water from the processing plants.
Constructed entirely in Blender.  The shells were constructed using a subdivision surface. Cleaned up non-manifold faces using MeshLab.

Fully parametric ring created with OpenSCAD.  
Learn how to make it yourself in the OpenSCAD tutorial in Getting Started With MakerBot: shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920026723.do

I have uploaded two versions of the code:
  • - Version 1.0 is the basic version from the tutorial in the Getting Started With MakerBot book.
  • - Version 2.0 is the same object, but the code creates the square cutouts using iteration over a vector of vectors (rotation).
    • Print with 2 extra shells for best finish results. The rings shown were printed on a MakerBot Replicator in several different colors of MakerBot ABS (white, blue, black) and translucent red Ultimachine PLA.

title: Geared Gear Cube - a more rugged version of Geared Cube, Hand Crank Edition.

description.text:
In the beginning there was Three Cube Gears by emmett. Then came Geared Cube, Hand Crank Edition by gzumwalt.
This is more rugged version of gzumwalt's model.
Designed in MOI, printed in Diamond Age PLA on an Ultimaker 1.
A short video is here: http://youtu.be/quQQPeJRWsE Important Note. To make this you need to make all of Three Cube Gears by emmett excepting only one of the large corner pieces and the central hub.

Notes.
The shaft is slightly larger in diameter to accommodate the pinion and the handle. This eases assembly.
The holes in the box should be cleaned/opened so the the shaft can rotate freely. The pinion (especially) should be a light press fit on the shaft. To assemble the pinion start the smaller end of the shaft into the box and into the pinion and then push the shaft towards the far end of the box, then fit the 'tool' around the shaft so that it fits between the pinion and the far side of the box. Then press or tap the shaft home.
I made the bolt at 100% fill, all else with 1.2mm walls and 20% fill.
Note that the threads on the bolt are non-standard. For those interested I've doubled the standard (coarse) ISO pitch and increased the included angle from 60 degrees to 90 degrees.
I opted for separate nuts rather than threaded holes in the box so that it is trivial to adjust the fit of the nuts to the bolts. If too loose or too tight scale the X and Y axes in your slicer. (Not the Z axis as that would affect the pitch of the thread.)

description.text:
This represents the plans for a longterm Mars base to support 6 people. Assembly
The construction of this base will require 15 to 18 launches of heavy lift rocket supporting a payload fairing of 10 meters high by 4 meters wide. The rocket will also need to be able to support up to 8000 kilograms of payload to Mars. The base will be composed of several robotic mobile modules. Once all of them have been delivered to Mars, they will begin pairing up and constructing themselves according to a predetermined layout. Each module will use an interlocking docking mechanism to connect to the other modules. The docking connector will also act as a distribution mechanism for networked resource tubing(NRT) such as water, waste,electricity, O2 and CO2. The walls of each module generally consist of 8cm thick titanium carbon nanotubes with exception of NRT's which account for over half of the overall thickness in some areas. Living Conditions
Two astronauts will be assigned to share a room module. Each room module will consist of a bunk bed, lavatory and shower. The astronauts will also share a small closet for storing clothing and other personal things. Adjacent to each room will be an emergancy evacuation closet. This closet will be pressurized and provides two space suits and weeks worth of rations. In the event of a hull breech astronauts will be able to quickly get suited up and assess any potential problems without having to go to the air lock. Command
The command module will consist of 3 large wall displays showing statistics about the base and 8 computer units for checking more detailed stats and for doing diagnostics. Lounge
The lounge module will be a place for taking a break and socializing. It will also have a television that shows latest information and entertainment from earth. Food
The kitchen module will house 12 industrial strength refrigeration units capable of storing up to 1000 individual frozen meal packets. There will also be an additional 1000 MRE meals for emergency use. The hydroponics module will be used to grow genetically modified fruits and vegetables using high grade artificial grow lights. Air and Water
The base will be filled with a nitrogen/oxygen atmosphere. CO2 will be sent to Hydroponics and O2 will be replenished using the plants or from the electrolysis module. Two water modules will be sent holding 50,000 gallons of water. Each module will have a waste container and water recycle unit. If the base is situated near the poles then robotic gatherers with on-board lasers can obtain ice chunks and return them to base for recycling also. Excess water can further be broken down into Oxygen (air) and Hydrogen (fuel cells) using the electrolysis module. Sandstorms and Radiation
In addition to thick titanium plating used in the base there will also be a large scale 3D printer sent to Mars, whose sole purpose is to create 3D blocks from Mars soil. This factory will consist of a conveyor belt and 2 robotic helpers. Their purpose will be to encapsulate the entire base with 1 meter thick bricks created from martian soil, to protect against radiation and sand storms. An added benefit of the factory is that it also produces water from the soil during the brick making process, which can be sent to the water recyclers. Transportation
Five two-passenger vehicles will be provided for exploration. These vehicles will be battery powered with a maximum range of 400 km and a total speed of 50km/h. The range can be greatly extended if a deployable solar panel or RTG charging unit is brought along. Power
The main source of power during the day will come from 10 solar panels with a total area of 40 square meters each (400 square meters total). During low light scenarios (night time, sandstorm) power will be provided by several large scale radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTGs) and hydrogen powered fuel cells. For safety and ease of service a power module will be sent to house the RTG, fuel cells and transformers.
Small robotic vacuum cleaners (similar to the ones on earth) will be used to clean the solar panels daily.

This a little corner bracket for putting on internal faces. Ideal for light-duty shelving and generally fixing two sheets of wood or MDF in a T-shape. It is a compact design which tucks right in the corner. Fits with 3 x 3mm diameter countersunk wood screws. Use at least 2 per side.
Not suitable for non-countersunk fasteners.

Mars Research Station Two (MaRS2) is an outpost devoted to testing agricultural and building methods on Mars. While the initial Mars landing focused on just getting us there and back alive, this second mission focuses on building the knowledge required for long-term habitation on Mars. MaRS2 is constructed out of combination of Martian materials, equipment landed in advance of the MaRS2 manned mission, and materials salvaged from the MaRS2 spacecraft. Inflatable Carbon Fiber Habs
--
This type of habitation can be deployed immediately, but it is vulnerable to puncture and offers no radiation protection. Although radiation on Mars' surface isn't an emergency concern, the crew has gotten a large dose of radiation on the trip from Earth and so will be eager to limit further lifetime exposure. (Inflatable habs are printed in black in the photos.) 3D-Printed Regolith Structures
--
To provide better radiation and structural protection, builder-bots print walls out of regolith mixed with a small amount of binder. The honeycombed tubes printed by the builder-bots can be filled with loose regolith to improve insulation, stability and shielding properties. With crane attachments builder-bots can also lift salvaged shielding into place. (Regolith structures are printed in red in the photos.) Salvaged Shielding
--
The in-flight hab for the trip from Earth is surrounded by radiation shielding. After the landing, the shielding is repurposed as ceilings for regolith structures and for a quonset hut hab. Inflatable habs can be tethered to their shielding covers and regolith walls to prevent the sudden collapse of a hab around its inhabitants in the event of a leak. (Salvaged shielding is printed in white in the photos.) Martian Garden
--
MaRS2 aims to determine whether viable martian soil can be created by fostering the growth of bacteria from a small sample of earth soil. The MaRS2 garden uses regolith walls with a salvaged shielding ceiling to protect the bacteria from radiation. Reflectors channel visible sunlight into the garden, but not high-energy particles. The garden is contained within a transparent inflatable. Salvaged Structures
--
While less spacious than the inflatable habs, the in-flight hab and the descent vehicle can both be used as ground structures. Sand bags filled with regolith can be piled on top of the in-flight hab's rigid structure to provide some radiation shielding. The descent vehicle can be used as a lab for potentially dangerous automated chemistry and fabrication experiments. It is visited by crew members for only short periods of time, and is kept disconnected from the main hab complex. (The in-flight hab and descent vehicle are printed in white in the photos.) Scale
--
The connector tunnels that link the inflatable habs are just big enough for a person to walk through.
I designed everything but the reflectors in OpenSCAD. I designed the reflectors in Tinkercad.

This is my interpretation of a martian base for human living and research.
It is intended to be built inside the Victoria Crater. This crater has a relatively small size and it has a flat surface inside wich makes it good for protection and construction.
The kit/base comes with: Observation and research room
Water and supplies room
Common room
Oxygen and gas station
Transportation area with 2 vehicles.
Sanitary Area
Entertainment from earth (TV Shows) and Fitness room
Temporary/Emergency room
Energy area
Solar panels
Vehicle
Victoria Crater (only printable if scaled) The kit has some moving parts.

The pieces are ready to print.
My advice is to print at high resolution (0.15 at least) with a low infill value (around 5 - 10 %)
Some parts need to be assembled and glued together.
The oxygen and gas module only needs glue in the tanks and maybe needs a minor adjustment. I'm not sure since I haven't printed any of this... yet.

The Challenge was to mount the Receiver in my garden pavillion beside of the Beamer (Public Viewing World Championship). Maybe somebody has the same Receiver and challenge.
Just slice with Cura by using 20% infill.
Curved loft of a hexagon to a circle, makes a nice shot glass.

This prints 3 layers with a .4 nozzle, pretty water tight.  I added a solid version so that you can print with no infill and pick your number of layers.  Also added an Autodesk Inventor file in case you're interested.

comments.text:
let me guess, you are on an older makerbot and thus stuck with repG?
try to use another slicer other than the included skeinforge.
Take Cura for a spin and see how much more you like that. One of the pre-sets in the simple mode is the 'vase' setting, which will print only the bottom + outline of a massive object, so you don't have hollow/skin your object yourself with all the nasty seam that includes.
That is, assuming you are on a makerbot. If you use any other printer that can run marlin firmware, you are good to go anyway.

For the MakerBot Mars base challenge. I designed this base to be as
modular as possible and as efficient as possible with its resources. The individual parts are purely conceptual and do not necessarily represent what one would find: such as scaling and aesthetics. Further considerations were technologies that might protect from high energy radiation, bare necessities and end-goals for sustaining life. Thank you for checking this thing out.

If there are any issues please let me know as I, as best I could, put this together between studying and taking final exams which will be over as of the day after the contest. I built all parts in SolidWorks with a scale of 3.5mm is 1 foot. I also was not able to finish making individual tubes for the sewage, water and power to connect each module. Should you be interested in building on my design I would be happy to e-mail the original .SLDPRT files.

This plate allows an SFX PSU to be mounted in the hole for an ATX PSU.

Print the plate.
Drill out the inner 3 holes with a 0.138 inch diameter drillbit.
Tap the outer 4 holes with a 6-32 tap. (I've found taping is unecessary)
Assemble! This plate is modified from stock SFX to match "CIT Micro Atx Power Supply". Stock SFX needs a width of 100, not 125. I've added reinforcing ridges around the outside.

author: darude

description.text:
Concept:
This is a scale model of a possible two to four person habitat to be shipped to mars. The idea is to have a majority of the craft built on earth, with only a few modifications and additions needed once on Mars. This kind of structure will be one of the first structures ever deployed on Mars, and dozens of these landed close to each other will create the first Mars research stations. Deploying the structure:
The round main body of the building is about 30 feet in diameter, about the maximum diameter of current rockets. The body will be build on earth and placed on a rocket to be blasted off and sent to Mars. Once there, it will re-enter the atmosphere and land itself anywhere on the planets surface where it will stay their permanently. Another payload will deliver the solar panels that will need to be installed manually on the building. Large Solar Panel And Its Uses:
A large solar panel will be installed on the building to provide all the power needed to run the habitat and science experiments on board. The solar panel is very large for multiple reasons; since the sun is farther from Mars, less light will be received on the planet surface and larger solar panels will generate more electricity. Another feature of the building is it will rotate and tilt the panel, allowing the solar panel to track the sun and be as efficient as possible to store electricity in batteries for the long nights and winters. With the building rotating, the ladders were designed not to run into the support legs, and the main weight of the building is the counterweight to the large panel hanging off the side. Another benefit to having a large solar panel that tracks the sun is it shades the entire building from the sun, and can double as a radiation shield for the building. The back of the panel can be lined with thick radiation shielding, and since it will track the sun you can protect the entire structure more efficiently with less shielding. You do not have to line the entire building with as much radiation shielding, meaning less weight to send to Mars. Machinery and Maintenance:
The roof of the structure will have all the machinery, batteries, Water tanks, Oxygen Tanks, and Waste Tanks needed to survive on mars. These will all be installed on Earth and delivered with the rest of the building. A ladder on the side of the building will allow people to access the machinery and make any repairs or maintenance required in the buildings lifetime. Inside of Building:
The building has two main doors, one on the outside of the building and another a few feet inside the front door. Having two doors allows the inner room to be pressurized, and a small entry room where all the Mars environment suits are kept, and a place to pressurize/depressurize people coming an going from the structure. The main room will house all the bunk beds, science equipment, and living space for its inhabitants. The people will spend most of their time living in one of these structures. Other versions of these structures can be designed and landed on the surface for specific uses. Special version can be made and used exclusively for food storage, water storage, or spare parts and survival gear. 3D Printing Info: I have not printed these objects yet, but it should print fine without may problems, I designed the parts with printing in mind. To assemble, the parts should all friction fit together snugly, with maybe a little filing. The roof and the doors are the only parts that needs to have supports to print properly, there is a lip around the bottom of them so it can fit tightly into the walls of the room. All the other parts do not require supports. The .stl files will need to be scaled up before printing, I haven't gotten the scale set correctly yet in inventor so all the parts are imported in very tiny. I scaled the files up by 800% to make my .thing file posted in the file section, they fit the print bed well with that size. Hope you guys like it, let me know if you have any questions, I would love to see peoples pictures of the prints! B-)
